subject: Re: RE: [junit] [TEST] JTest v4.5 and what is says about JUnit
msgSnippet: Quoth Chappell, Simon P: [ whether NullPtrExc is a good thing to throw (v. IllegalArgExc) ] ... Jumping in here on a point I haven t really understood in all
messageBody:
Quoth Chappell, Simon P:
[ whether NullPtrExc is a good thing to throw (v. IllegalArgExc) ]
> You are correct, but I actually meant that at runtime,
> my code does not know why your code threw an NPE.

Jumping in here on a point I haven't really understood in all this
discussion:

I can see that it is at least somewhat useful for the human
troubleshooter reading the stack trace to be able to see quickly
that the problem is an invalid argument, and not a surprising null
somewhere in the guts of the method; this may well speed up the
troubleshooting, and makes an argument for throwing IllegalArgExc
as a matter of style.

But why would the calling code care? For example, why would it
react differently to an IllegalArgExc than to any random
RuntimeException?
